Posts.Content: May 19, 2014 06:09AM teaspoon wrote: Hi Deane0978, Sorry for your worries and fear, and I hope that all goes well today.  To answer your question, the timeframe for pathology results varies by facility.  Mine took one week and no less, but I see here on this site that many women get their biopsy results within several days.  Your doctor should be able to tell you today what the timeframe is at your hospital.   The waiting and wondering is so agonizing.  Wishing you all the best.  Keep us posted.
Posts.Title: scared and confused Deanne0978 Infobabe

Posts.Content: May 12, 2014 06:01PM teaspoon wrote: Hi pattyn and clynnoli, Like you, pattyn, my 50th birthday brought me a mammography call-back (bi-rads 4) for micro calcifications, a referral to a breast surgeon and a stereotactic biopsy.  There were delays along the way.  My path results were benign except for the discovery of a radial scar, which my surgeon recommended be excised.  So, like you, clynnoli, I had excisional surgery of the radial scar last month.  Those path results were also benign, and I've been healing up from the surgery.  I just wanted to send you both my good wishes - it was really not long ago that I was in your shoes, and everyone on this site knows how hard it is to wait and worry.  I just wanted to remind you that in all your worries at this stage, there's also the very real possibility of benign results.  I know, statistics are of little consolation when you're anxious;  I had a hard time believing that my results were actually benign, because I'd so totally prepared myself for a diagnosis of some sort or another.  Hang in there - you're in a good place to ask questions and get support.  Take care and keep us posted on how you're doing.
Posts.Title: Having an excisional biopsy pattyn FL_sunshine

Posts.Content: May 24, 2014 07:52AM - edited May 24, 2014 07:58AM by teaspoon Hi rayofsunshine, Sorry that you find yourself here, and that you've been having such a difficult time of it this week.  I know that others will chime in soon (it's a holiday weekend and may be quiet here) and just wanted to reach out.  I remember how hard it is to be where you are right now!   The radiologist sounds like a Jerk with a capital J (hope you never have to see him again), and I'm glad you found your way to a breast surgeon.  I hope that you feel good about her. It sounds like she tried to explain the recommended procedure to you and what you've shared about that conversation makes a lot of sense to me.   My situation is not exactly parallel to yours - I didn't have pain, I had calcifications found on mammogram Bi-rads 4, went through stereotactic biopsy, results were B9, but had to go back for wire-guided excisional surgery (lumpectomy) of a radial scar, results were B9.  Along the way, I switched treatment providers/centers because that's what I needed to do to feel I was in the best of care.   One step at a time, get with a medical team you can trust, request copies of your treatment and pathology reports, don't get ahead of yourself, don't "borrow trouble", stay busy - all of these pieces of advice helped me.  Probably the best preparation for what's ahead is to do exactly what you're doing - choose a doctor and treatment center that you can feel good about, ask questions, get support (glad you're here!), know the timeline and your options, stay as sane as possible (not easy in the limbo of waiting, and if the anxiety is really crippling for you, you can get meds to help), and continue to live your life without this being a dark cloud.  The unknowns are hard, and statistics aren't always very personally reassuring even if the odds are in your favor, but make sure to leave room to think of a B9 outcome, not just the worst case scenario (which is where our minds naturally go when we're scared!).  So, as to the specifics of an excisional biopsy, perhaps you'll first have a wire-guided procedure (did your BS indicate this?), which may be done with mammography or an ultrasound and typically performed by a radiologist - this procedure "locates" and "marks" the target area for surgery.   The area will be numbed up, and they'll insert a special needle to the target area, then a wire is inserted through the needle and attached to the lesion, the needle is removed, and the thin wire left in until surgery.  Depending on the size/location of the lesion (and whether there are multiple lesions), sometimes there's more than one wire required.  You'll then go to surgery, where you'll get your IV anesthesia, and will be under the care of your BS and her team.  She's already told you where the incision will be and what to expect in terms of the pathology report timeframe. I was given an elastic compression tube top post-surgery.  I wore it for a full week and it was comfortable.  The bandages stayed on for two days, and when I finally got to remove those and take a shower, there were still overlapping steri-strips on the actual incision, so I didn't see the actual incision until those strips fell off about 10 days later (I was told not to pull those off because my surgeon had closed the incision with surgical glue).  I wore a sports bra for a couple more weeks mainly because I didn't want a regular bra to chafe on the incision area (my incision was underneath - on the crease of my breast about 2 inches long).  They prescribed Vicodin for post-surgery pain, and I took that for one day but hated being on it, and switched to Ibuprofen, and that was all that I needed for a few days. As you're in pain now and have been for a while, if I were you, I'd want to get into surgery asap and just get to the other side of all of this.  Removing the lesion will hopefully give you some relief.  And of course the best relief of all is no pain, and a B9 pathology report, which I hope is what you get to hear!   Please keep us posted on how you're doing and the date of your surgery.
Posts.Title: Planning for excisional biopsy... rayofsunshine Mouche

Posts.Content: May 24, 2014 12:57PM teaspoon wrote: Hope I didn't alarm you about the wire-guided possibility, it could be that it won't be part of your surgery at all.  Good for you for putting together a list of questions - we're all newbies when we're new to this (!) and feeling our way through the dark.    It doesn't help when we have to deal with jerks along the way - your anger and trust issues are understandable. Thanks, hope you can enjoy your long weekend too - Tuesday will be here soon enough and then you can get start figuring out what's next.   As I read that you're needing a family member to come some distance to be with you, I wanted to make sure that you know that lumpectomies are typically same-day surgery.  I was at the hospital from 7:30 am till about 3:30 pm, the guide-wire procedure took almost two hours, but the surgery itself was only an hour.  I was back to work the next day (okay, maybe that was a bit too heroic) thanks to well-positioned ice packs (especially the pink Barbie-pillow-sized ones they gave me post-surgery which were my best friends for a while).   So whatever family member can accompany you on surgery day, hopefully all will go smoothly medically and you'll also get to actually enjoy a few days together, since it may not be often that you get to see family or they get to see you wherever you're living now. Take care!
Posts.Title: Planning for excisional biopsy... rayofsunshine Mouche

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2014 07:10AM teaspoon wrote: I don't actually know if my mammo results were BI-RADS 4(A,B or C) or BI-RADS 5, since I wasn't given a copy of the report (I'll request it today when I go in for my pre-admission testing) and because I didn't know at the time to ask that question of my surgeon.    I asked her what pattern she saw in the micros and she just said "a cluster".    I realize that it's the upcoming biopsy results that matter... I just can't stand waiting another whole week till the surgery, and then another for results!
Posts.Title: scared silly teaspoon teaspoon

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2014 05:47PM teaspoon wrote: I've been silent for a while because I really didn't have any updates.  However, I'm back today because I wanted to share the news that biopsy attempt #3 at a different hospital worked like a charm for me.  As of a few hours ago, I have successfully completed a biopsy of the microcalc cluster.  They were able to do the stereotactic biopsy this time around without any problem (still not sure why the other hospital so quickly concluded it was impossible…), so (fingers crossed) I won't need the excisional biopsy as well.  I feel confirmed in my decision to switch treatment centers - the ease of this procedure today was proof positive for me that I'm in the best of hands.  So now I only have to wait until Tuesday morning for my results, which is only a few short days in comparison to this long stretch of starts and stops since December.  Anyhow, even the soreness I feel now following the procedure is a happy reminder that it's finally DONE, out of my hands, and just a matter of getting the low-down early next week and taking it from there.
Posts.Title: scared silly teaspoon teaspoon

Posts.Content: Feb 28, 2014 05:36PM teaspoon wrote: Thanks AZ85048, SarahJane7374 and Geekyknitter for your good wishes.
Posts.Title: scared silly teaspoon teaspoon

Posts.Content: teaspoon wrote: I just discovered this discussion board and so appreciate that you're all out there supporting one another.  I'm a really private person and this isn't my style to reach out in this way, but here goes.  I just turned 50, married with 4 kids, not yet diagnosed, but very worried.  Through a routine mammogram before Christmas, micro calcifications were found in my right breast.  More mammograms were taken confirming this suspicious area.  Last week my surgeon was unsuccessful in doing a stereotactic core needle biopsy because of my small size and the location against the chest wall.  That was upsetting to me, as I'd already waited a month to get to that point, only to find out on the table that it was a no-go.  So I am scheduled to go in for wire-placement (under local anesthesia) and surgery (under general anesthesia) next week.  I get light-headed during routine mammograms, so I'm figuring that I will have a hard time tolerating the guide-wire insertion and subsequent mammograms. I feel like such a big baby!!  I wish I had a time machine and could fast forward to have this behind me rather than in front of me … hard to carry on with life as if everything's fine and dandy right now!  I have only told my husband and my sister about this, don't want to worry others unnecessarily, particularly my children and my parents.    I guess that I've let fear get the best of me, because I've basically convinced myself that I have cancer, even before there's been an actual biopsy…  so hard to take this one day at a time.  Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2014 01:14PM teaspoon wrote: Got my results this morning from my biopsy of the microcalcs.  The short and sweet of it:    Benign.  Wow and phew!  Still getting my head around it.  Had braced myself for all sorts of other news. The rest of the story is that there was an "incidental finding" - although not detected in imaging (I have extremely dense tissue), the pathologist found evidence of a radial scar in the biopsy sample.   My BS is now scheduling wire-guided excisional surgery to remove the whole lesion next month, to be 100% sure it's clear. Time to research radial scars, which apparently are neither "radial" nor "scars".  My BS answered my initial questions (and those of my husband, who was with me today), but this is something I'm just starting to learn about. And I forgot to ask for a copy of my path report while I was there. Still healing from the needle biopsy last week - not too sore, but very bruised.  The marker that was placed is now also the "target" for the radial scar excision, so I'll only need one wire placed in the next procedure. Not sure if I should post in "high risk for cancer" forum (or elsewhere?) about radial scars?

Posts.Content: Feb 28, 2014 05:18PM - edited Feb 28, 2014 05:32PM by teaspoon Hi worrierbynature,  Your name says it all!  Thanks for reaching out, and welcome here (I see this was your first post) ! Sorry to hear that you've also had a hiccup on your way to a completed biopsy.  The wait can be incredibly wearing.  I hope that you can find good company and support here in the meanwhile. Regarding the incomplete stereotactic, yes, we do have that in common and it stinks to prepare yourself for something that doesn't or can't happen and thus means a further delay.  I don't know anything about implants, but it does happen that the stereotactic is not always possible for a myriad of reasons.   I wish you well as you wait until March 10th, and I hope that all goes smoothly, and of course with a benign result.  Try to trust that you're on your way, especially now that you've now met with your BS and s/he has confirmed that the wire-guided excisional is the next step for you and that you are on the calendar for the procedure that is recommended for you.  Hopefully by St Patrick's Day you'll be all set with your results and it'll be reason to celebrate!   Please keep us all posted.  Everyone here can relate to how hard it is to wait.  Hang in there.
Posts.Title: scared silly teaspoon teaspoon

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2014 12:31PM teaspoon wrote: Thank you Melissa and jb777 for your calming words.  It's really comforting to hear about others' courage in going through these days of waiting, and the good outcomes that are indeed possible.   One question I have is whether my surgeon fully considered a seated machine for the stereotactic biopsy for me (I was "too small" for the face down machine, no matter how they twisted my arm/shoulder through) - this hadn't even been offered as an option up-front (is it because i"m not eligible or because the breast care center doesn't have one??  don't know).  She immediately said that surgical biopsy was the next step.
Posts.Title: scared silly teaspoon teaspoon

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2014 09:04PM teaspoon wrote: Dear AZ80548, AnxietyAnne, and lekker: My thanks to each of you for your thoughtfulness in replying and your sharing your own experiences.  I am humbled to see what some of you on this site have had as health challenges, and yet you are so willing and able to give back to others your hard-earned wisdom and encouraging words. I am glad that I decided to write here - I feel less alone, and yes, less scared, now that I know that I am in the company of so many others who've been through this (and worse) - all survivors. I'll share - by way of some comic relief - today I also decided to tell my brother about my upcoming surgery, etc.  I described to him the  stereotactic biopsy procedure that was tried on me last week.   When he heard that the doctor, the tech and the nurse were all "under" the raised table working on my exposed breast, he called it a "Jiffy Boob" procedure!  It was so good to laugh about it!

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2014 09:02PM teaspoon wrote: Christycain17, Thank you for writing here and joining me in this waiting room!  And thank you for keeping me in your prayers.  I will keep you in mine next Tuesday and hope that all goes well for you.  The timing of your post here means a lot to me because I have been hesitant to post my latest news because, well, it's not great news, and I don't want to scare anyone, but others have asked me to keep them posted too, and it helps to feel less alone in sharing our challenges.  I'm afraid that I'm in a small minority in that I am now 0 for 2 in the biopsy department:  (1) failed stereotactic biopsy and (2) this week, aborted guide-wire localization because I became medically unstable just after the needles were successfully placed (guide wire not yet threaded).   I was whisked off to the ER (yes, with needles sticking out of my breast) where I spent the day being worked up.  My first time ever being "medically unstable" and being the patient in an ER (been there many times with loved ones).  My surgery had to be cancelled because of my condition.  Talk about crying like a baby!   It broke my heart to have those carefully placed needles removed because I knew it meant starting all over again another time.   A repeat of the guide-wire localization and then excisional surgery is postponed until I can be cleared for procedures, so I have to have more doctor visits before anything can even be scheduled.   Back to square one!  I'm sore from the procedure and all that ensued, but mostly just feeling very defeated that I've actually taken steps backward rather than forward. Thanks, all, for being here.
Posts.Title: scared silly teaspoon teaspoon

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2014 10:32PM teaspoon wrote: Sorry, I just realized that I hadn't yet responded to your posts for me, Christycain17 and AZ85048.  Thank you for the words of encouragement through what has been my own little trying time   of waiting and hoping.  I don't have anything to report as of yet regarding progress towards scheduling a repeat of the biopsy procedure, but have been inquiring about moving from the smallish local hospital (where I had the 2 failed biopsies) to an accredited breast care center at a larger hospital for my next go-around. This may mean a bit more of a delay on top of the 2 months I've already waited for a successful biopsy - but I am hoping that it will ultimately be a step in the right direction.

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2014 04:51PM teaspoon wrote: Hi Petitegal127, I just caught up on all your posts and see that we do have some parallels going on here.    When you say "stereotactic wire guided lumpectomy", does that mean that they insert the wires while you're face down on a stereotactic table?  I ask because my experience of the stereotactic procedure involved core needle biopsy while face-down on the stereotactic table, and my experience of the wire-guided procedure was sitting up in a chair in radiology, to be followed by the lumpectomy in the operating room.   The latter is what I'll have on March 31st, just a few days after you, and I just assumed I'd be sitting up for it like the last try at another hospital, but am not positive about this.  One thing I have learned is that not all stereotactic tables are alike - I had one experience that was a no-go at a local hospital, and another experience that was a no problem at a bigger/better hospital with a brand spanking new "latest edition" stereotactic table, designed (evidently) to better accommodate 'even' small-breasted women.  (Who knew? !) Hoping all goes well with you.   Keep us posted - I'll be thinking about you.
